title: African Students Organization
descriptionSnippet: African Students Organization is about globalization. We invite various world views, while learning about each other, through the variety of cultures exposed to us at Texas Christian University.
fullDescription: African Students Organization is about globalization. We invite various world views, while learning about each other, through the variety of cultures exposed to us at Texas Christian University. ASO educates individuals on how African heritage influences global society! African heritage is not only about being African, it is about looking at one's own heritage, accepting it, loving it, and sharing it with others who WANT to know more about it.

title: Athletic Training Students Association
descriptionSnippet: We are an organization made up of current athletic training students at TCU. As an organization we support our peers educationally and emotionally, reach out to the community, and strive to educate the campus about athletic training and sports medicine.
fullDescription: As an organization made up of athletic training students at TCU we strive to grow professionally, be active members of the surrounding community, and educate others about the profession of Athletic Training.

title: Chi Upsilon Sigma National Latin Sorority, Inc.
descriptionSnippet: The first independent Latin sorority, known as Women of Wisdom. Promote political, educational, cultural, and social awareness. Aim to educate, elevate, and empower ALL women. Originally founded on April 29, 1980 and founded at TCU on April 13, 2003 by...
fullDescription: The first independent Latin sorority, known as Women of Wisdom. Promote political, educational, cultural, and social awareness. Aim to educate, elevate, and empower ALL women. Originally founded on April 29, 1980 and founded at TCU on April 13, 2003 by two strong independent women. Our motto is "Wisdom Through Education." We value Leadership, Sisterhood, Service and Character.

title: Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc
descriptionSnippet: The Iota Eta Chapter of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc. was charted on the campus of Texas Christian University on April 22, 1972 by seven illustrious Delta Women. The Iota Eta chapter serves the TCU community through various empowerment sessions, pub...
fullDescription: The Iota Eta Chapter of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc. was charted on the campus of Texas Christian University on April 22, 1972 by seven illustrious Delta Women. T he Iota Eta chapter serves the TCU community through various empowerment sessions, public service opportunities, and socials. Delta Sigma Theta (ΔΣΘ) is a non-profit Greek-lettered sorority of college-educated women who perform public service and place emphasis on the African American community. Delta Sigma Theta was founded on January 13, 1913, at Howard University by twenty-two illustrious women and now, over 100 years later, Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Inc. has become the largest African-American Greek-lettered sorority in the world. Membership in Delta Sigma Theta is open to any woman who meets the membership requirements, regardless of race, nationality, or religion. Women may join through undergraduate chapters at a college or university, or after acquiring a college degree through a graduate chapter. The Grand Chapter has a membership of more than 350,000 predominantly African-American, college-educated women, and educated Caucasian, Asian, Native American, Hispanic, and African women. The sorority currently has 950-plus alumnae and collegiate chapters located in the United States, England, Japan (Tokyo and Okinawa), Germany, Bermuda, the Bahamas, Seoul, Saint Thomas and Saint Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands; Haiti and Jamaica.[1] Delta Sigma Theta is a member of multiple organizations, including the National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC) — an organization of nine international Greek-letter sororities and fraternities - as well as the NAACP, and the National Council of Negro Women (NCNW). The current national president is Cynthia M. A. Butler-McIntyre.
twitterDescription: The Illustrious Iota Eta Chapter of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc. was chartered April 22, 1972 by seven women of fortitude at Texas Christian University.

title: Lambda Theta Phi Latin Fraternity Inc. - Beta Pi Chapter
descriptionSnippet: Since our inception on December 1, 1975, Lambda Theta Phi has grown coast to coast as the first and largest Latin fraternity in the United States. Founded at Kean University, in Union, New Jersey, our 14 Founding Fathers congregated with the vision to ...
fullDescription: Since our inception on December 1, 1975, Lambda Theta Phi has grown coast to coast as the first and largest Latin fraternity in the United States. Founded at Kean University, in Union, New Jersey, our 14 Founding Fathers congregated with the vision to unite all Latinos regardless of nationality. Today, Lambda prides itself on its multi-cultural brotherhood of gentlemen from different creeds, nationalities, and religious beliefs. Our brothers, nationwide, stay true to our mottos “En la union, esta la fuerza”/”In unity, there is strength” and “Chivalry Above Self,” and set the precedent of what it means to be fraternal men, gentlemen, and role models in the community.
twitterDescription: The Beta Pi Chapter of Lambda Theta Phi Latin Fraternity Inc. Chartered November 18th, 2001. Leaders of the Latino Greek Movement, Since December 1st, 1975.

title: Omega Psi Phi Fraternity, Inc.
descriptionSnippet: On Friday evening, November 17, 1911, three Howard University undergraduate students, with the assistance of their faculty adviser, gave birth to the Omega Psi Phi Fraternity. This event occurred in the office of biology Professor Ernest E. Just, the f...
fullDescription: On Friday evening, November 17, 1911, three Howard University undergraduate students, with the assistance of their faculty adviser, gave birth to the Omega Psi Phi Fraternity. This event occurred in the office of biology Professor Ernest E. Just, the faculty adviser, in the Science Hall (now known as Thirkield Hall). The three liberal arts students were Edgar A. Love, Oscar J. Cooper and Frank Coleman. From the initials of the Greek phrase meaning "friendship is essential to the soul," the name Omega Psi Phi was derived. The phrase was selected as the motto. Manhood, scholarship, perseverance and uplift were adopted as cardinal principles. A decision was made regarding the design for the pin and emblem, and thus ended the first meeting of the Omega Psi Phi Fraternity.

title: Student Foundation
descriptionSnippet: In a continuing effort to involve all campus groups interested in the advancement and support of Texas Christian University, the university established the TCU Student Foundation in the fall of 1976. Student Foundation was organized for the general pur...
fullDescription: In a continuing effort to involve all campus groups interested in the advancement and support of Texas Christian University, the university established the TCU Student Foundation in the fall of 1976. Student Foundation was organized for the general purpose of enlisting and motivating outstanding TCU students to promote the welfare of the University. Members of Student Foundation guide campus tours of prospective students and families, provide support and assistance at alumni events, and call donors to thank them for their gifts to the university.
twitterDescription: Members of Student Foundation give tours, host alumni events, as well as be generally awesome. We've been walking backwards since 1976!

title: TCU Students for Life
descriptionSnippet: TCU Students for Life is a Pro-Life Organization on campus dedicated to education, respectful activism and promoting the Pro-Life movement. Meetings for Fall 2018 are TBD. Email tcustudentsforlife@hotmail.com to be added to the GroupMe.
fullDescription: Members of TCU Students for Life work to peacefully save lives threatened by induced abortion, euthanasia and destruction of human embryos for research. In furtherance of these goals, members seek to promote respect for life at Texas Christian University and in the surrounding community, to educate on life issues through campus outreach and activism, to help those in need so that life is a promising choice and to work with others who share common goals.

title: Texas Christian University Dance Marathon
descriptionSnippet: Dance Marathon is a year long fundraiser to raise money for Cook Children's Medical Center. The year ends with a 12 hour long event where all participants remain on their feet for the kids that can't. It is an event filled with games, music, and lots o...
fullDescription: Dance Marathon is a year long fundraiser to raise money for Cook Children's Medical Center. The year ends with a 12 hour long event where all participants remain on their feet for the kids that can't. It is an event filled with games, music, and lots of dancing. Throughout the year, there are different fundraising events to support the event, the hospital, and the families that are effected. The main focus is on the kids that endure countless trials through their sicknesses, and to help raise money to make them better.
twitterDescription: Making miracles for the kids & families at Cook Children's Medical Center #FTK #ChooseJoy

title: Wesley Foundation
descriptionSnippet: Thanks for checking us out! We are a religious community of Christian students at TCU who are seeking to grow in faith and serve our community in and around TCU.
fullDescription: Welcome! We are a religious community of Christian students at TCU who are seeking to grow in faith and serve our community of students at TCU. The Wesley Foundation is historically based in the Methodist tradition and named after John Wesley, the founder of Methodism. We welcome students of all faiths to worship and grow in faith with us. We worship, pray, study the Word, serve our city, eat, have fun, and do life together. Come hang out at our building, grab a soda, and throw your hammock up on the pergola. We hope to see you around!
twitterDescription: energizing & empowering TCU for Christian life by nurturing them in faith development, supporting their vocation exploration & engaging in mission.

title: Women of Empowerment
descriptionSnippet: To unite, build community, and provide support for all female students of color. To educate, support, and promote thought-provoking discussions for women of color at TCU.
fullDescription: An organization here that caters to the needs of minority women by giving them an outlet to express themselves as well as network and make connections.
twitterDescription: Our mission is to unite, build community, and provide support for all female students of color.

title: Young Democratic Leaders
descriptionSnippet: Young Democratic Leaders is a Democratic student organization focused on education, representation, and leadership. It is our goal to educate students about the Democratic Party by hosting elected officials, candidates, and Party officials on campus. W...
fullDescription: Young Democratic Leaders (YDL) is the Democratic student organization on the campus of Texas Christian University. Our purpose is to provide representation for liberal-minded students, educate the TCU community about the Democratic Party, and enhance the leadership skills of our members. Additionally, YDL will promote civil and respectful discourse as we pursue an enhanced political dialogue on campus.
twitterDescription: Young Democratic Leaders is the Democratic Student Organization on the campus of Texas Christian University.
